{{Infobox person |name = Aida de Acosta |image = MrsOrenRoot.png |birth_name = Aida de Acosta |birth_date = July 28, 1884 |birth_place = [[Elberon, New Jersey]] |death_date = {{Death date and age|1962|05|26|1884|07|28}} |nationality = U.S. |ethnicity = Cuban-Spanish American |other_names = Mrs. Oren Root Sr.; Mrs. Henry Breckinridge |known_for = First woman to fly a powered aircraft solo
Founder of first U.S. eye institute
Executive director of first U.S. [[eye bank]] |spouse = Oren Root Sr., Henry Breckinridge |children = Oren Root Jr., Alva de Acosta Root |parents = Ricardo de Acosta, Micaela Hernández de Alba y de Alba }} '''Aida de Acosta Root Breckinridge''' (July 28, 1884 – May 26, 1962) was an American socialite and the first woman to fly a powered aircraft solo.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_62IjQ-XQScC&pg=PA189&lpg=PA189&dq=%22Elihu+Root%22+aida+divorce&source=bl&ots=WM8JoyitPQ&sig=s6Ktu6M6z5PZ4LNYUtl7JhpWHDE&hl=en&ei=t2ZFSp-ICZmMtgfGsOGxAg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1|title=Latinas in the United States: a historical encyclopedia|first=Vicki|last=Ruíz|author2=Virginia Sánchez Korrol|publisher=Indiana University Press|year=2006|isbn=0-253-34681-9|page=189}} In 1903, while in [[Paris]] with her mother, she caught her first glimpse of [[dirigible]]s. She then proceeded to take only three flight lessons, before taking to the sky by herself. Later in life, after losing sight in one eye to [[glaucoma]], she became an advocate for improved eye care and was executive director of the first [[eye bank]] in America.{{cite book|title=America's political dynasties|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=n4HZVCTQvkEC&pg=PA268&dq=%22oren+root%22+%22Aida+de+Acosta%22&num=100&ei=Be9EStK2H5WKzQSEqbRN|first=Stephen|last=Hess|page=268|publisher=Transaction Publishers|year=1997|isbn=1-56000-911-X}}{{cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,896333,00.html|title=Milestones|date=June 8, 1962|work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]}} ==Early life== Aida was born in the [[Elberon, New Jersey|Elberon]] section of [[Long Branch, New Jersey]], in 1884 to Ricardo de Acosta, a steamship executive of [[Cuba]]n descent, and Micaela Hernández de Alba y de Alba, reputedly a descendant of the Alba family, famous in the history of [[Spain]] as the [[House of Alba|Dukes of Alba]].{{cite book|title=Current Biography Yearbook|first=Maxine|last=Block|author2=Anna Herthe Rothe|author3= Marjorie Dent Candee|publisher=H. W. Wilson Co.|year=1954|page=115}} Among her seven siblings were the writers and socialites [[Mercedes de Acosta]] and [[Rita de Acosta Lydig]]. ==The flight== On June 27, 1903, in Paris, when Acosta was nineteen, Brazilian pioneer aviator [[Alberto Santos-Dumont]] showed her how to operate his personal dirigible, “No. 9.” Santos-Dumont was the toast of Paris at the time, flying his dirigible downtown to his favorite restaurant and parking it on the street while he had dinner. Acosta flew Santos-Dumont’s aircraft solo from Paris to [[Château de Bagatelle]] while Santos-Dumont rode his bicycle along below, waving his arms and shouting advice.{{cite web |url=http://www.fhwa.dot.gov/ohim/wmntrans2.pdf |format=pdf |title=Women in Transportation: Changing America's History, Reference Materials |publisher=U.S. Department of Transportation |pages=10 |date=March 1998 |accessdate=}} Acosta later recalled that upon her first landing, Santos-Dumont asked her how she had fared. "It is very nice, M. Santos-Dumont," she replied. "''Mademoiselle,''" he cried, "''vous êtes la première aero-chauffeuse du monde!''" ("Miss, you are the first woman aero-driver in the world!"). She was in fact the first woman to pilot any kind of motorized aircraft, nearly six months before the [[Wright brothers]] first flew in a heavier-than-air powered aircraft.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1310&dat=19530812&id=NIgRAAAAIBAJ&sjid=tuIDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5208,435372|work=Eugene Register-Guard|title=She Beat Wright Bros. – American Girl Flew First Powered Aircraft|date=Aug 12, 1953}} The first flight ended in the [[polo]] field at [[Château de Bagatelle|Bagatelle]] at the northern end of the [[Bois de Boulogne]], during a match between the American team and the British team. Spectators assisted her from the basket. After watching some polo with Santos-Dumont, Acosta climbed back into the basket and flew the machine back to [[Neuilly-sur-Seine|Neuilly St. James]], the entire trip lasting one and a half hours. ==Flight aftermath== [[Image:aida-1903.jpg|right|thumb|Aida de Acosta flying to a polo match in 1903]] Hearing about the flight, her parents were appalled. They were certain that no man would marry a woman who had done such a thing, so they managed to hush it all up until many years later when in the 1930s she recounted the story to her husband and a young naval officer named Lieutenant George Calnan over dinner. Acosta is the only person that Santos-Dumont ever permitted to fly any of his many aircraft. Also, Santos-Dumont, a lifelong bachelor with no known romantic ties, kept a photograph of Acosta on his desk, next to a vase of fresh flowers, for the rest of his life. Nonetheless, there is no indication that Santos-Dumont and Acosta stayed in touch after her flight. Upon Santos-Dumont's death Acosta was reported as saying that she hardly knew the man. ==Personal life== Aida de Acosta married: *Oren Root III, son of [[Oren Root II]] and nephew of American statesman and [[Nobel Peace Prize]] laureate [[Elihu Root]], in 1908; they divorced in 1922. They had a son, [[Oren Root IV]] (1911-1995), and a daughter Alva de Acosta Root (born 1914 and named for suffragette-heiress [[Alva Belmont]]).Alva Root married, in 1935, Charles Fiske Bound.{{cite news|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1908/11/06/104766977.pdf|title=Miss Ada De Acosta Bride Of Oren Root; Bridegroom a Nephew of Secretary Root and Manager of the Metropolitan Railway. Elihu Root at Wedding |work=[[The New York Times]]|date=November 6, 1908|page=7 | format=PDF}}{{cite news|work=[[The New York Times]]|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1995/01/16/obituaries/oren-root-83-banking-official-and-a-rockefeller-adviser-dies.html|title=Oren Root, 83, Banking Official And a Rockefeller Adviser, Dies|date=January 16, 1995 | first=Eric | last=Pace | accessdate=April 23, 2010}}{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1911/06/14/archives/son-born-to-mr-and-mrs-oren-root.html|title=Son Born to Mr. and Mrs. Oren Root|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=June 14, 1911}}{{cite news|title=Daughter Born to Mrs. Oren Root|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1914/05/03/100087960.pdf|date=May 3, 1914|work=[[The New York Times]] | format=PDF}}{{cite news|title=HOLIDAY PARTY HELD FOR ALVA DE A. ROOT; Mrs. Henry Breckinridge Entertains for Her Debutante Daughter at Colony Club|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1932/12/20/archives/holiday-party-held-for-alva-de-a-root-mrs-henry-breckinridge.html|date=December 20, 1932|work=[[The New York Times]]}}{{cite news|work=[[New York Tribune]]|date=July 29, 1917|title=Society's kiddies|url=http://frontiers.loc.gov/service/sgp/sgpnytr/1917/191707/19170729/0004.pdf|accessdate=2009-06-27}} *Colonel [[Henry S. Breckinridge]], whom she married in 1927 and divorced in 1947. He was attorney to [[Charles A. Lindbergh]] during the Lindbergh kidnapping case, and assistant secretary of war under [[Woodrow Wilson]].{{cite web|url=http://www.ourcampaigns.com/CandidateDetail.html?CandidateID=18814|title=Breckinridge, Henry Skillman|publisher=ourcampaigns.com|accessdate=2009-06-26}} ==Eye care advocacy== In 1922, Aida was afflicted with [[glaucoma]]. Her ophthalmologist was famed eye specialist William H. Wilmer, whom ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine called "the greatest eye surgeon the U.S. has ever had."{{cite news|work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|title= Medicine: At Johns Hopkins|date=October 28, 1929|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,728673,00.html}} She eventually lost sight in one eye, but Dr. Wilmer’s care saved her other eye, and inspired her to organize a fund-raising campaign that resulted in $3 million to fund the establishment in 1925 of the Wilmer Eye Institute in [[Johns Hopkins Hospital]], the first eye institute in the U.S.{{cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,719910,00.html|title=Eye Hospital|date=February 23, 1925|work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]}}{{cite news|work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|title=Medicine: Wilmer Institute|date=November 9, 1925|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,728673,00.html}} In 1945 she became Executive Director of the Eye-Bank for Sight Restoration in New York, the first [[eye bank]] in the U.S.{{cite web|url=http://www.eyedonation.org/history.html|title=History|publisher=The Eye-Bank for Sight Restoration|accessdate=2009-06-26| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090601205431/http://www.eyedonation.org/history.html| archivedate= 1 June 2009 | deadurl= no}} ==Death== She died in Bedford, New York, at the age of 81.{{cite news|work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|title=Milestones|date=June 9, 1962|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,896333,00.html}} ==See also== *[[Hélène Dutrieu]] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==Further reading== * ''American Women'', by Gail Collins * [http://www.airpower.au.af.mil/apjinternational/apj-s/3trimes04/acostaeng.html Air & Space Power Journal] * Hoffman, P.
